dialogues.text: CU. DANIEL CALDECOT PLAINVIEW. (D.C. PLAINVIEW) — 1908 22 A few (six) years later. He is dressed well now. slight s of some wealth. overcoat, haircut, clean shaven, etc. We nothing but him as he speaks;

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, I’ve traveled over half our state to get here this evening. I couldn't get away sooner because my new well was coming in at Coyote Hills and I had to see about it. That well is now flowing at two thousand barrels and it’s paying me an income of five thousand dollars a week. I have two others drilling and I have sixteen producing at Antelope. So — Ladies and Gentlemen — if I say I’m an oil man, you will agree. (beat) You have a great chance here — but bear in mind: you can loose it all if you’re not careful. Out of all men that beg for a chance to drill your lots, maybe one in twenty will be oil men; the rest will be speculators — men trying to get between you and the oil men — to get some of the money that ought by rights come to you. Even if you find one that has money, and means to drill, he’1ll maybe know nothing about drilling and he’1ll have to hire out the job on contract — and then you’re depending on a contractor that’s tryin’ to rush the job through — so he can get another contract just as quick as he can. This is way that this works. An OC VOICE INTERRUPTS, LOUDLY; Daniel holds his composu

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I do my own drilling and the men that work for me, work for me and they are men I know. I make it my business to be there and see to their work. I don’t lose my tools in the hole and spend months fishing for them; I don’t botch the cementing off and let water in the hole and ruin the whole lease. REVEAL, AT THAT MOMENT, young H.W. (age 7) He is standing Daniel and looking at the group OC. Daniel and H.W.;

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I'm fixed like no other company in this field and that’s because my Coyote Hills well has just come in — I have a string of tools all ready to put to work..I can load a rig onto trucks and have them here in a week. I have business connections so I can get the lumber for the derrick — such things go by friendship in a rush like this. And this is why I can guarantee to start drilling and put up the cash to back my word. I assure you, whatever the others promise to do, when it comes to the showdown, they won't be there...

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: It’s not up to me to say how you’re going to divide the royalty. But let me say this; whatever you give up so you can get together — it will be smart compared to what you may loose by delay. The crooks and the gamblers are near and the wolf is scratching the door. Ladies and Gentlemen, take it from me as an oil man — humbly — there aren’t going to be many gushers here at Signal Hill. A field plays out very quick. In two or three years, these wells will be dry — even this discovery well that’s gushing down the road and has everyone so crazy. So my suggestion, with respect, is take a smaller share of royalty and we will see that it’s a small share of a bigger royalty. That, ladies and gentleman, is what I had to say. HOLD ON THE ROOM. Everyone has taken this in, then: THE R

dialogues.text: 24 1 BANKSIDE HOME — NIGHT. 24 INT. DANIEL is now sitting with a nice, mild mannered man: JIM BANKSIDE (50s) his WIFE sits with him and their TWO SONS and 12. BEAT. HW sits beside Daniel and a bit behind;

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Bankside, I’m not going to waste your time and I’d like it if you didn’t waste mine. If you want to sign with me we can have a well drilling within ten days. Your lot is further North from the discovery well up here so it means we will probably have to dig deeper. If there's as much oil up here as I think there is, it will be harder to reach but once we find it we can take it right out. But we have to act quickly because very soon these grounds will dry up. I need you to know what you want to do. Because of the distance from the discovery well I’1l pay you a smaller royalty than you’d get down there — but I'll give you a thousand dollar bonus on your lot.

dialogues.speaker: BANKSIDE
dialogues.text: what royalty?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: A sixth — now that’s standard. And a guarantee to start drilling within ten days — which isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: My name is Fletcher Hamilton. nice to meet you, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: I work with Mr. Plainview.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: four hundred dollars...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: It’s six now. I’m leaving my home for good, so I need this -- I want six hundred dollars. give it to me or I'll go somewhere else. Daniel reaches into his pocket — he has $300 — Fletcher g an envelope and gives him another $300.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: I come from a town called Little Boston in Isabella County. ANGLE, MOMENTS LATER. They have a map spread out and tacked up on the wall. DAN FLETCHER, HW and PAUL over it as he points.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: this is us here. spur station here at Little Boston. The Sunday ranch is what you’re looking for. There’s a sheep trail that leads you there — it’s a mile from town heading west — not far. just through a small pass — near the base of the hills. follow the sheep trail.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: And where did Standard buy up?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Here and here. he points to an area about thirty miles north west.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: your family’s name is Sunday?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: that’s right.  BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: how many in your family?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: My father and mother and and my sisters and my younger brother, Eli. H.W. How many sisters do you have?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Two. Mary and Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Paul.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: Does your family know about the oil that you say is there?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. My Uncle always said there was oil there — but I don’t know what they heard or what they think.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: what do you grow?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: it's goats. a goat farm. I told you: there’s nothing grows up there but weeds.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: water?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: it’s salty. you drill a well, it hard not to get salt water. (beat) The oil is there. I’m telling you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: I wanna go now. so: good luck to you.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: you can stay here tonight --  27 28 18

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: No. I wanna go now. I wanna leave. Daniel walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: If I travel all the way there and I find out that you're a liar, I’ll find you and I’1l take more than my money back, is that alright with you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: yessir. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: nice luck to you. good bye. He leaves. HOLD with Daniel, Fletcher and HW.

dialogues.speaker: FLETCHER
dialogues.text: you know there was an earthquake up there a few days ago... (beat) Anything he’s seeing on the ground could just be loose stuff set free... HOLD. CuT TO: EXT, TRAIN DEPOT/LITTLE BOSTON, CALIFORNIA — LATE DAY. 27 CAMERA looks down a long stretch of TRAIN TRACKS that cut across a dry, flat, empty valley floor. We can see, in the distance, the faint trace of DANIEL an driving in their CAR on a road that runs parallel to the tracks. They bounce up and down, dust trail behind them —

dialogues.speaker: WITH THEM AS THEY ARRIVE AT
dialogues.text: THE TRAIN DEPOT OF LITTLE BOSTON. We see some small, roll hills in the distance... They PARK THEIR CAR next to the SPUR STATION, UNLOAD SOME CAMPING EQUPIMENT FROM THEIR CAR and start walking off..w the TOWN OF LITTLE BOSTON NEARBY... DANIEL and HW walk the road on the outskirts of town and towards the hills --  29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’re walking with the HEAVY CAMPING EQUIPMENT. H.W. starts to fall a bit, with the camping equipment, Da catches him, props him up a bit;

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Alright? yeah. They walk some more until Daniel sees something coming up in the distance, says to HW;

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Remember your silence..(walk beside me, not behind me.) CAMERA PANS LFT, becomes THEIR POV: Coming towards them, the distance is a MAN. This is ABEL SUNDAY (50s) He is ve frail, small, worn;

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Good evening. They gain ground, get closer. THREE SHOT. HOLD.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: My name is Daniel Plainview. This is my son HW.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Are you hunting?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: We’re hunting for quail. We were told there might be a good place to camp up here near the Sunday ranch...

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: This is the Sunday ranch. you can camp here.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: do you have water?  30 20

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Yes. They arrive at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: (extends his hand) I am Abel Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Pleasure to meet you. We heard there was an earthquake here a few days ago is that right?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Your family?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Yeah, all fine, thank you. We’ve got some milk if you’d like, goat's milk up at the ranch if that’s ok..

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: That'd be fine. They continue to chat as they walk up the road. IN the di are some minor rolling hills...they head around a bend..a see a CHURCH ON A HILL...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men come up to the small, very run down HOME. Standing, waiting outside is the SUNDAY FAMILY: MOTHER SUNDAY (50s) RUTH SUNDAY (aged 12) MARY SUNDAY (ag and a very skinny, man/boy, the son: ELI SUNDAY (aged 18) They make introductions, say hello, etc. About fifty yard the house is a large oak tree;

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Can we set a tent over here? we'll be out of your way here —  HW goes off 2

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: that’s fine. Eli, help this boy right now and get them some water.

dialogues.speaker: HW
dialogues.text: I’ve got it. to get some water. Eli just stands.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Plainview — would you like that milk now?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: That’s fine thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Go, Mary. Ruth help them with their tent --

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: No, please. We set ourselves on this camping trip, we’ve got to do the camping.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: The eggs, Ruth. Ruth goes off to get some eggs. HW comes back with some w

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Do you have any bread?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: We have potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Potatoes would be nice, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: I’1l have them boil you up some potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: That’s alright, I thought maybe we'd make a fire. I wanted to work with my son on making a fire.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Eli, would you get them some wood? Eli reluctantly goes off to get some wood, Daniel walks o Abel, extends his hand;  31 22

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Thank you for your hospitality, Abel. we'll stay out of your way, just hunting quail —

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry we don’t have any bread. Corn just doesn’t fill out in the hills here. It’s mostly rock and we don’t have room to raise the grain... They chat a bit more as -- DISSOLVE TO: INT. SUNDAY RANCH/NIGHT — LATER. 31 DANIEL and HW and ABEL SUNDAY sit close to the FIRE. Just back a bit, on stones, sits the rest of the FAMILY a Abel directs the girls to clear and wash their dishes — t collect the dishes, and then;

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Brother, may I ask you a personal question?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Are you saved?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: And you’ve been washed in Blood?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yes, brother. We’ve been washed.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: What is your church?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Our church is called The Church of the World.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: I don’t know that Church. I don’t know what their message is --

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yes.  23

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Can you tell me about the message of the Church of the World?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Well, Brother Abel, we are told in the Book not to discuss our faith with stangers. Even if they’re so nice and helpful.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: We're told in our book, “The Lord has called us to preach the Gospel unto them.”

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s right. “And the Gospel must first be published among all nations.”

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: That's right!

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: But according to our faith, we believe that we get to know a man through friendship — and business — and we talk about faith later. ELI speaks up;

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: May I ask a question?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Yes, Eli?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What does your Church teach about earthquakes?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: About the earthquakes? Like the earthquake you had up here? (beat) We are taught that it is God’s mighty power.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: My son is a healer and a vessel for the Holy Spirit. He has a church...  32 33 24

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Our earthquake means that the Holy Spirit has grown weary of drunkeness and lying in the world. (beat) Have you been doing any of these things? H.W. No we haven't. DANIEL (to Eli) No, son. We haven't.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: thank you. No one seems to know what to say next, so they stand and good night and head back to their house. Daniel, H.W. get their tent.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: EXT. SUNDAY RANCH — DAWN 32 DANIEL and HW put out their morning fire, collect their H GEAR and head off —

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. HILLS NEARBY/CANYON — MORNING. 33 CAMERA leads/follows them as they move..H.W. and DANIEL c their shotguns..while they HUNT QUAIL. DANIEL fires first. We follow H.W. -- watch him SHOOT. ANOTHER ANGLE. The same thing. HW raises the GUN and shoots, hitting ano

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Go get ‘em. H.W. runs off. In running to retrieve the quail he steps in something an stumbles a bit. He stops, turns back — recognizes somethi slowly moves towards it --

dialogues.speaker: CU. H.W
dialogues.text: he looks closer. BEAT. He looks down towards his shoes. T  34 35

dialogues.speaker: 35A
dialogues.text: 25 ANGLE, HW. He runs back to his Father.

dialogues.speaker: HW
dialogues.text: Dad.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HW
dialogues.text: Look at my shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand over a minor PATCH OF TAR/OIL SLICK that bubbl the surface..DANIEL is kneeling over it, dips a stick int moves it about, looks at it against the light — ANGLE, CU. DANIEL. He takes out a box of matches and attempts to light the s on fire. Nothing. ANGLE. CU. THE OIL. He moves to another area of the oil slick and dips the st again, takes some out, strikes match and it FLAMES. HOLD.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: This is earthquake stuff set loose. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA behind them as they climb up on top of a small hil CAMERA rises above them and reveals the landscape; rollin hills. rocky and dusty and rough. not pretty. They look o place. HOLD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’re walking, DANIEL is feeling the ground beneath his SOUND SEQUENCE. Feel of the footsteps, crunch, etc.

dialogues.speaker: 36A
dialogues.text: 37 26 EXT. BANDY RANCH/NEARBY CANYON — LATER 36 They come upon a SMALL, RUNDOWN HOME at the base of some MOUNTAINS in canyon. Off to the side, in a run down PEN a PIGS. There is a POOL OF FOUL SMELLING SULPHUR WATER surroundin the pen, THEY COVER THEIR FACES, LOOK AROUND;

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: He puts his pigs here - near the sulphur water to kill their fleas and cure the mange. This is a nice place to drill. This is your pay sand. ANGLE, BANDY HOUSE. They move to the house..knock and get no answer..they OPE DOOR...

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE, UPON THE WALLS, THERE ARE RELIGIOUS ARTIFACTS. 36
dialogues.text: Crucifixions, portraits of MARY, etc. A small ALTAR with CANDLES. DANIEL and H.W. take a good look, then exit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk/talk quickly, carrying the quail;

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: so-so. if there’s anything here..we take it to the sea -- we can go into town and see a map - but what we do — we take a pipeline from here to Port Hueneme or Santa Paula and we make a deal with Union Oil — this is what we do and we don’t need the railroads and the shipping costs anymore, you see?  38 27

dialogues.speaker: AW
dialogues.text: yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: you see that?

dialogues.speaker: AW
dialogues.text: yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: and then we're making money. we make the real money that we should be making and we’re not throwing it away -- otherwise it’s just mud.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SUNDAY RANCH — DUSK. 38 CAMERA holds on DANIEL. The Sunday Family and H.W. eat th quail, minor conversation..then:

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: what would you say is a fair price for this lot, Abel? Everyone stops eating and looks at Daniel: Abel is very e

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: The Lord has sent you here. The Prophet Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: yes. let me finish telling you —

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: This is according to the revelation of the True Word. This is it.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I think it is, yes. now what would you say is a fair price?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: Five dollars an acre.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six dollars. thank you, Eli.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: And with the improvements I’ve made at five hundred --

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I'll offer to buy the ranch for thirty-seven hundred dollars. (beat) That's three thousand and seven hundred dollars. BEAT. MOTHER SUNDAY speaks:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUNDAY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to leave here, this isn’t for sale.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: no, no, no. you don’t have to leave. You may stay here as long as you like and I will give you my word — you can have all the farming rights — what we can do is develop a lease — I will lease you the land after the purchase for the next ninety-nine years at ten dollars a year.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER SUNDAY
dialogues.text: We don’t have any money.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I’m giving you some... Everything gets quiet.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Does this seem fair to you?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL SUNDAY
dialogues.text: This is according to the Revelation — Eli, this is according to --

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: And what about the rock oil?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: «well,yes,what..? 28  29

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: And what do you want to do about the rock oil?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: what about it?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: We have oil here. that’s worth something.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: do you have someone who can drill for it?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Do you think there's oil here?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I know there is.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: it’s very expensive to drill..to get it up out of the ground. have you ever tried that before?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: how much is it?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: «costly.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: what would you give us for that?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: SOMETHING YOU DON’T KNOW!

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: what would you like, Eli?  30

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I think that you should share the mineral rights with my Church. you've given us the farming rights, now why not share the mineral rights? BEAT. Eli and Daniel hold a look on each other;

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: If we decide to drill for oil, if the well begins to produce I'll give your Church a five thousand dollar signing bonus.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: that’s not enough.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: do you want to find someone else that’s gonna come up here and drill? Eli? make the investment and do all the work that goes into it? I can hunt for quail on another ranch just as easily as I can here. BEAT. Eli is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I would be happy to be a supporter of your Church as long as I can. with the bonus only..I do have some connections that could get us started drilling for oil..how do you feel about that Abel?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: yes. what Eli says.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Fine. Fine. Let’s draw up some contracts and let’s try.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 3 39 EXT. TRAIN DEPOT/LITTLE BOSTON — MORNING (START MUSIC) DANIEL and HW are driven on CART AND HORSE by ELI..They a the TRAIN DEPOT AREA and their PARKED CAR.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: you can just leave us here. ELI (re: the car) is this yours?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: looks like it. DANIEL hops down, grabs some camping equipment and moves the car. As HW moves to climb down, he gets a little stuc ELI gives HW a little PUSH, ACCIDENTALY/ON PURPOSE and he straight to the ground. Daniel turns and looks --

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: you alright?

dialogues.speaker: HW
dialogues.text: yeah. They start getting their car packed up.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: That’s a very nice car.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Maybe you’1l have one just like it someday, Eli. Daniel and H.W. get in the car. Eli turns around the othe direction, Daniel drives off — and honks the horn, heads into town --

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 40 INT. ROSE REAL ESTATE, INSURANCE, LOANS OFFICE — MORNI CAMERA behind them as they enter and greet the real estat AL ROSE (40s)

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: AL ROSE
dialogues.text: hello. can I help you?  32

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Well..I‘d like to talk to you. I’m looking for some land, I've just bought the Sunday ranch, and... .where’s the map? ANGLE, MOMENTS LATER. A MAP of the entire area is spread out on the desk in fro them; They look it over. Daniel takes out a small notepad pencil, works it throughout;

dialogues.speaker: AL ROSE
dialogues.text: There’s the Bandy tract which is the neighboring lot. He has over 600 acres --

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: and what about this?

dialogues.speaker: AL ROSE
dialogues.text: AC Maude, Blodget, Redlick...Carr...

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What’s it held at?

dialogues.speaker: AL ROSE
dialogues.text: Six dollars an acre.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: and what about this?

dialogues.speaker: AL ROSE
dialogues.text: That’s the Belvins and that could be got, I’m sure.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Can everything around here be got?

dialogues.speaker: AL ROSE
dialogues.text: BEAT. THEN; Daniel looks up.

dialogues.speaker: AL ROSE
dialogues.text: sure. They sit down;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to buy this for me and I want you to be my man, Al. But I want it just enough to pay fair price — and I don’t want it any more than that. People don’t need to start boosting prices. If they do, you can tell them to forget it and I’1l forget it too. You can collect your commission from the seller in the usual way and on top of that you can have five percent from me. And that’1l be what makes you a man. You seem aware enough that this should be done quickly and quietly so there aren’t any ideas that there’s a boom on — does this make sense to you?

dialogues.speaker: AL ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes. but I’m not sure how quietly --

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Son, can you go to the car and get my bag please? HW goes outside —

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: you make the buying for an unknown client — you buy the options for cash — that means if someone is home you should be able to make a deal right there —

dialogues.speaker: AL ROSE
dialogues.text: you have this money on you?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I have some and I can have a wire for more in the morning. have the options ready so they can be signed on the spot — HW comes back inside with a leather BAG and takes out som FORMS.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I carry everything in my car. These forms will make it easy for you — so let's type up an agreement to list these tracts and purchase the Sunday tract.  41 34 ANGLE, AT THE TYPEWRITER — LATER. Al types out some contracts. Daniel stands over/behind hi says:

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: If I needed to get a real road in Little Boston that went out to the Sunday Ranch -- who would be a good man to talk to? Al Rose looks up from the typewriter at him..

dialogues.speaker: AL ROSE
dialogues.text: I’d talk to Jake Coffey.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: What's Jake's business?

dialogues.speaker: AL ROSE
dialogues.text: Hay and Feed..and Insurance. cur TO: INT. TRAIN DEPOT — DAY — LATER. 41 DANIEL and HW come in to do some business with the TRAIN MAN: HOWARD SOMMERVILLE (50s) He introduces himself, make small talk and goes about making filling out a TELEGRAM, it over;

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Howard, who’s the best man in town to contact for a water well?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: Sam Davis.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: can you contact him for me and have him meet my son out at the Sunday ranch?

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD
dialogues.text: to talk to your son?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: To drill a proper well. My son knows what I'd like done. Can I use that telephone?  35 Daniel moves towards the TELPHONE across the room, while Howard the number he’d like dialed..Howard works the swit and places the call for him, Daniel is connected with Fle ANGLE, HW. he looks out the window and sees: THE TRAIN COMES DOWN TH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he is speaking with Fletcher, telling him to come up, etc His attention turns to the TRAIN as it PULLS UP OUTSIDE T WINDOW. ANGLE, GENE BLAIZE and CHARLIE WHRIGHTSMAN. (50s) Two other INDEPENDENT OIL MEN step off the train and walk the depot; They see HW and start to chat him up.. Daniel finishes his call with Fletcher and walks over;

dialogues.speaker: GENE BLAIZE
dialogues.text: Plainview and Son.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Hello, Gene. Charlie. You guys are a long way from Signal Hill. You on your way somewhere else?

dialogues.speaker: GENE BLAIZE
dialogues.text: Passing through and looking around. Funny to see you.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Funny.

dialogues.speaker: GENE BLAIZE
dialogues.text: Congratulations on your well, I heard that hit nicely --

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: 300 barrels a day. you remember my son, H.W.?

dialogues.speaker: GENE BLAIZE
dialogues.text: You boys are a regular family business...

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: you boys are a little late...

dialogues.speaker: GENE BLAIZE
dialogues.text: What'd you find?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found some interesting prospects.

dialogues.speaker: GENE BLAIZE
dialogues.text: Did you hear Standard bought up?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: «I did hear. further North.

dialogues.speaker: GENE BLAIZE
dialogues.text: that’s right.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I like you Gene, and I wanna tell you: If you’re gonna make a play: look east, cause there’s a lot around here that’s been taken. I’d rather have it be you than someone else.

dialogues.speaker: WHRIGHTSMAN
dialogues.text: Life must be easy when you've got such a cute face to carry around with you.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
